unnormalised: AIIMS Delhi reported a significant rise in stroke cases among young adults, particularly post-Diwali. Dr. Rajesh Mehra, HoD Neurology, noted a 30% increase in patients aged 30-45 presenting with symptoms like sudden weakness, speech difficulty, and severe headache. Several cases were linked to lifestyle changes during the festive season, including increased intake of sweets and oily foods.
normalised: A-I-I-M-S Delhi reported a significant rise in stroke cases among young adults, particularly post-Diwali. Doctor Rajesh Mehra, H-o-D Neurology, noted a thirty percent increase in patients aged thirty to forty five presenting with symptoms like sudden weakness, speech difficulty, and severe headache. Several cases were linked to lifestyle changes during the festive season, including increased intake of sweets and oily foods.

unnormalised: The hospital saw a surge in admissions over the past 2 weeks. According to data, 65% of the stroke patients admitted in November had a history of hypertension or diabetes. Many were unaware of their conditions or were non-compliant with medications. One patient, a 38-year-old software engineer named Rohan Sharma, experienced a stroke after a late-night Diwali party.

unnormalised: "We are urging individuals, especially those with risk factors, to get regular check-ups," said Dr. Mehra. "Early diagnosis and treatment, like thrombolysis within the first 4.5 hrs, are crucial for better outcomes. Also, controlling blood pressure and blood sugar levels is vital." The Neurology department has launched a public awareness campaign with pamphlets in both Hindi & English.

unnormalised: The campaign, kicking off on 15/12/2024, will focus on educating the public about stroke symptoms (using the acronym FAST – Face, Arms, Speech, Time) and preventive measures. AIIMS plans to conduct free screening camps in various Delhi neighbourhoods. They aim to reduce the incidence of stroke by 20% in the next year. The next camp is scheduled for 22nd Dec at Karol Bagh.
